intro: Dissochaeta sarawakensis, commonly known as the Sarawak dandelion, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia, particularly found in Borneo. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of numerous small florets. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded habitats such as forest understories and swampy areas. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are yellow and arranged in a single head. Dissochaeta sarawakensis plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators and contributing to soil stabilization.
